fact: Australia is the only country that is also a continent, and it is home to the Great Barrier Reef—the largest coral reef system in the world.
Brazil contains the majority of the Amazon Rainforest, the largest tropical rainforest on Earth, covering about 60% of the country.
Russia is the largest country in the world, spanning 11 time zones and two continents, Europe and Asia.
Egypt is home to the Nile River, historically considered the world’s longest river and the lifeblood of ancient civilizations.
The United States features diverse geography, including the Grand Canyon, one of the world’s deepest and most spectacular canyons.
Indonesia is the world’s largest archipelago, made up of over 18,000 islands, and sits on the Pacific Ring of Fire, making it prone to earthquakes and volcanoes.
Canada has more lakes than any other country in the world, containing almost 20% of the world’s fresh water.
China is home to the Himalayas, including Mount Everest, the world’s highest peak, on its border with Nepal.
The Congo Rainforest, found mostly in the DRC, is the second largest tropical rainforest in the world after the Amazon.
Argentina shares Iguazu Falls with Brazil, the largest waterfall system in the world by number of individual falls.
Nepal contains eight of the world’s ten highest mountain peaks, including Mount Everest.
Switzerland is famous for the Alps, a major mountain range that covers about 60% of the country’s total area.
Greenland is the world’s largest island and is covered by the second largest ice sheet after Antarctica.
Tanzania is home to Mount Kilimanjaro, Africa’s highest peak and the world’s tallest free-standing mountain.
Iceland sits atop the Mid-Atlantic Ridge and is one of the most volcanically active countries in the world, with geysers, hot springs, and glaciers.
